repnme.cdata!:
Niger - Pilot Private Irrigation, Natural
            Resources Management, and Agro-Pastoral Export Promotion Projects

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the three Niger projects
            vary greatly.  The Pilot Private Irrigation Project (PPIP)
            had a highly satisfactory outcome; risk to the development
            outcome was significant; and both Bank and Borrower
            performances were satisfactory. The Natural Resources
            Management Project (NRMP) had a satisfactory outcome, risk
            to the development outcome was moderate; and satisfactory
            performances by both the Bank and Borrower. The
            Agro-Pastoral Export Promotion Project (APEP) had a  highly
            unsatisfactory outcome; risk to the development outcome was
            high; and unsatisfactory performances by both the Bank and
            the Borrower. Lessons learned from the projects included:
            empowering communities to take control of the implementation
            of their own development plans improves community ownership
            and motivation to engage in sustainable development
            practices. Export development needs to follow a well defined
            strategy, and a commodity chain approach needs to emphasize
            producer-exporter linkages. Similar agricultural development
            projects in neighboring countries can have opposite outcomes
            due to the quality of project preparation, the level of
            engagement of the implementing agencies, and the prevailing
            land tenure security situation.

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Natural Resources
            Management Project in Niger was  satisfactory, and project
            sustainability is regarded as likely. The overall
            performances of both the World Bank and the Borrower were
            adjudged as satisfactory. A number of factors relating to
            community empowerment in rural areas influenced the
            probability of the project's success: intensive
            sensitization/awareness-raising and flexibility in forming
            organizations; the overall approach to project
            implementation, which augmented social capital accumulation
            and reinforced community ownership as well as the
            introduction of community-based procurement procedures,
            which significantly improved motivation and allowed for new
            capacities and competencies to be developed within the
            communities; community co-financing and "sweat
            labor" the quick and transparent process of approving
            or rejecting community submissions for project development
            funds. The initial introduction of CBPP after the Mid-Term
            Review met with some resistance and procrastination on the
            part of some government officials and community leaders.
            Although these obstacles were overcome through vigorous
            intervention by the Ministerial authorities, they should not
            be underestimated. Entrenched constituencies may jeopardize
            such initiatives and full Government support is an absolute
            requisite for such a project to succeed. Other lessons
            learned regarded the flexible approach to project
            eligibility criteria that was well matched to the diversity
            of community demands. Lastly, the project demonstrated that:
            1) community ownership of NRM development plans and projects
            depends on building a sound knowledge among community
            members of land and resources through simple diagnostic
            analyses; 2) a combination of capacity building and the
            implementation of a wide range of development activities is
            important to ensure the sustainability of NRM activities; 3)
            the distribution of donkey carts as positive incentives to
            youth workers demonstrated the need to directly and
            specificly target women and youth in micro-development
            activities in order to enhance probability of success and
            sustainability; and 4) decentralized NRM activities need to
            be complemented by policy reforms (in particular on land
            tenure) and institutional development components.

abstracts.cdata!:
The primary objective of the Rural
            Resource Management Project is to slow down, stop and
            ultimately reverse the current process of land and natural
            resource degradation in order to secure sustainable
            agricultural production and growth, alleviate poverty and
            improve the living conditions of Niger's rural
            communities. In addition, the project has two specific
            objectives: 1) to assist selected rural communities in
            different agro-ecological zones in designing and
            implementing management plans for their lands and provide
            them with the necessary know-how, information, technical and
            financial resources and the proper institutional and legal
            framework to successfully carry out such an endeavor; and 2)
            to assist the government in building up a national capacity
            to promote, assist and coordinate the diverse natural
            resource management (NRM) initiatives underway in Niger in
            the framework of the National Natural Resources Management
            Program (NNRMP), and help prepare NRM policies and
            strategies, based on lessons learned from field experience.
            The principal components of the project are: 1) direct
            technical and financial assistance to communities for the
            design and implementation of Community-Based Natural
            Resource Management (CBNRM) plans involving about 280
            selected communities in five districts, and assistance
            through ongoing NRM projects to another 100 communities in
            Niger; 2) provision of services to help achieve the
            project's objectives, namely: human resource
            development, national assessment of the state of natural
            resources, natural resource information networking, research
            and studies; and 3) assistance to decision-makers in
            devising national NRM policies and strategies.
